author: By Natalie Kitroeff, Simon Romero and Emiliano Rodríguez Mega
title: Claudia Sheinbaum Makes History as First Woman Elected to Lead Mexico
description: A climate scientist and former mayor, Ms. Sheinbaum became the first woman and Jewish person elected as president of the country.
content: Claudia Sheinbaum, a climate scientist and former mayor of Mexico City, won her nation’s elections on Sunday in a landslide victory that brought a double milestone: She became the first woman, and the first Jewish person, to be elected president of Mexico.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi
title: Stuck at the Start
description: In the last few years, many Americans have gotten stuck in their starter house.
content: Buying your first home has long been a milestone of adulthood. So has selling your first home and moving into something bigger. But in the last few years, many Americans have gotten stuck in their starter house.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Netanyahu May Face a Choice Between a Truce and His Government’s Survival
description: The Israeli prime minister has been put on the spot by President Biden’s announcement outlining a proposal for a truce.
content: For months, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has refused to offer a timeline for ending the war against Hamas in Gaza, a stance his critics see as a political tactic. But he has been put on the spot by President Biden’s announcement outlining a proposal for a truce.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘A Building Employee Greeted Us With a Broad Smile Every Day’
description: Recalling a first job, trading places in a crowded subway car and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lydia Polgreen and Max Strasser
title: South Africa Confronts Israel and Its Own Democracy
description: Lydia Polgreen reports from Cape Town about the myth of the country’s exceptionalism and its moral authority in the war on Gaza.
content: In a special intercontinental episode of “Matter of Opinion,” Lydia Polgreen reports from South Africa as the country challenges Israel for its attack on Rafah in southern Gaza.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David French
title: Civil Liberties Make for Strange Bedfellows
description: Sonia Sotomayor helped protect the country from Donald Trump, and she did it in an unexpected way.
content: Last Thursday, Sonia Sotomayor helped protect the country from Donald Trump, and she did it in an unexpected way — by defending the National Rifle Association.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tammy LaGorce
title: Rupert Murdoch Marries for the Fifth Time
description: Mr. Murdoch, the 93-year-old media mogul, married Elena Zhukova, a retired molecular biologist, Saturday at Moraga, his Bel Air vineyard estate in Los Angeles.
content: Rupert Murdoch, who retired from the boards of Fox and News Corporation last year, walked down an outdoor aisle under blue skies to exchange vows on Saturday with Elena Zhukova, his fifth bride, at Moraga, his Tuscan-style vineyard estate in the hills of the Bel Air neighborhood of Los Angeles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esi Edugyan
title: A Tribal Eviction, a Blood Secret and the Knotty Questions of Belonging
description: In “Fire Exit,” a white man raised on a reservation wrestles with whether he should reveal to his daughter the complications of her heritage.
content: There’s a lovely clarity to Morgan Talty’s debut novel, “Fire Exit.” He is especially bracing about the losses that can accrue with time. When we first meet Charles Lamosway, Talty’s middle-aged protagonist, he is at a crossroads: Mental illness and dementia threaten to engulf his mother; he has been evicted from the Native reservation where he has lived all his life; and, most painful of all, his daughter doesn’t know him. That last problem, at least, is within his power to change. He strongly feels “she needed to know that her blood was her blood,” to be aware of her “connection to a past time and people.”
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Widespread Harm of Nuclear Testing
description: Readers, including Christie Brinkley, discuss the dangers. Also: About apostrophes; oversight of legislative initiatives; congestion pricing.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By George Grasso
title: I Supervised New York City Judges. Juan Merchan Put On a Master Class in the Trump Trial.
description: This is how judges can remain pillars for the rule of law in America.
content: I spent almost 13 years as a judge in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx. I supervised judges presiding over a wide spectrum of cases, dealing with complex legal issues, angry victims, difficult defendants and intense media scrutiny. The job can at times be thankless and frustrating.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clyde Haberman
title: David Levy, Ex-Laborer Who Became a Top Israeli Leader, Dies at 86
description: A native of Morocco, he often embodied the resentment of North Africans and Middle Eastern Jews toward European Israelis.
content: David Levy, a Moroccan-born Israeli who rose from ditch digger to Israel’s political heights, often embodying the resentments of Jews of North African and Middle Eastern origin who felt ill-treated by Europe-rooted elites, died on Sunday at a hospital in Jerusalem. He was 86.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Diamond
title: A Productive Chat on the Significance of ‘Slack’
description: Once referring to those prone to idle behavior, the word has come somewhat full circle.
content: In 2011, The New York Times published an article examining the assertion by some elders that millennials are “a generation of slackers.” Such assumptions about younger generations are nothing new. “Even Aristotle and Plato were said to have expressed similar feelings about the slacker youth of their times,” the article read. While we might use the word “slack” to refer to a certain messaging app today, “it appears in some of our earliest Old English written records,” the lexicographer Kory Stamper said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Baker
title: A Felon in the Oval Office Would Test the American System
description: Some are wondering how the Constitution’s checks and balances, meant to hold presidents accountable, would work if the next president elected were already a felon.
content: The revolutionary hero Patrick Henry knew this day would come. He might not have anticipated all the particulars, such as the porn actress in the hotel room and the illicit payoff to keep her quiet. But he feared that eventually a criminal might occupy the presidency and use his powers to thwart anyone who sought to hold him accountable. “Away with your president,” he declared, “we shall have a king.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ken Belson
title: N.H.L.’s Move to Salt Lake City Is Latest Sports Downsizing
description: Professional leagues are embracing smaller markets in their search for newer stadiums and arenas and the potential for more devoted fan bases.
content: Sometimes, smaller is better.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: The Connections Companion No. 358, June 3, 2024
description: Scroll down to reveal a hint for each category of today’s Connections, or head to the comments for community hints and conversation.
content: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius, Maia Coleman and Erin Nolan
title: Intense Security at Peaceful Parade for Israel in Manhattan
description: The annual parade focused this year on the hostages in Gaza. Thousands marched, and with many streets blocked off, there were few protesters.
content: Thousands of supporters of Israel marched along Fifth Avenue on Sunday during a heavily policed Israel Day parade that took on a more somber tone this year as the war in Gaza enters its eighth month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robin Pogrebin
title: Anatomy of a Success Story: How One Artist Broke Through
description: Hugo McCloud has gone from designing fountains and furniture to his fifth show with an established New York gallery.
content: Each year in the art world, lesser-known artists percolate into public consciousness — most obviously at auctions like those that recently concluded in New York, which saw prices exceeding estimates for up-and-comers like Jadé Fadojutimi, Lucy Bull and Michaela Yearwood-Dan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Bishop
title: They Spent Their Life Savings on Life Coaching
description: Some people who wanted to improve their lives and careers through coaching found themselves trapped in what they described as a pyramid scheme.
content: To an outsider, Billiejo Mullett is someone who has her head firmly screwed on. She’s smart and educated — a registered nurse who works for a medical insurance provider — and balances her career with a busy family life.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ali Watkins
title: Wildfire Near San Francisco Burns About 14,000 Acres
description: The blaze, the Corral Fire, was 50 percent contained by Sunday evening. It was the largest so far in this year’s California wildfire season.
content: A fast-spreading wildfire east of San Francisco has burned about 14,000 acres, prompting an evacuation order and for a time shutting down major highways, according to public safety alerts and Cal Fire, California’s firefighting agency.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra E. Petri and Amanda Holpuch
title: 1 Dead and 24 Wounded in Akron Shooting, Police Say
description: The shooting happened at a large birthday party in Akron, Ohio, early on Sunday, officials said. At least two of those wounded were in critical condition.
content: Two dozen people were wounded and one person was killed in a shooting at a large birthday party in Akron, Ohio, early on Sunday morning, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Goldstein
title: The Long Life of Yuppie Scum
description: In “Triumph of the Yuppies,” Tom McGrath revels in the stories of a generation that turned its back on protest and bought into consumer culture.
content: In 1967, a bushy-haired Jerry Rubin walked onto the balcony of the New York Stock Exchange with a few friends and flung dollar bills down to the trading floor. Rubin, a co-founder of the activist group the Yippies, was delighted when the traders on the floor piled on top of one another to grab the money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yousur Al-Hlou and Masha Froliak
title: 46 Children Were Taken From Ukraine. Many Are Up for Adoption in Russia.
description: The New York Times traced how a web of officials and politicians aligned with President Vladimir V. Putin’s party carried out a campaign to permanently transfer Ukrainian children from Kherson.
content: As news of Russia’s invasion spread through Ukraine on Feb. 24, 2022, Dr. Natalia Lukina was waiting for a taxi at her home.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner
title: Netanyahu may be forced to choose between a cease-fire and his government’s survival.
description: For months, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has refused to offer a timeline for ending the war against Hamas in Gaza, a reticence that his critics see as a political tactic. But he has been put on the spot this weekend by President Biden’s announcement outlining a proposal for a truce.
content: For months, Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel has refused to offer a timeline for ending the war against Hamas in Gaza, a reticence that his critics see as a political tactic. But he has been put on the spot this weekend by President Biden’s announcement outlining a proposal for a truce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dahlia Scheindlin
title: Yoav Gallant Has Shown Defiance. Will He Again?
description: Israel is facing a stark choice about its future. Defense Minister Yoav Gallant represents a critical role in the path it takes.
content: Last month, Yoav Gallant told Israelis that Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu was leading the nation astray. Mr. Gallant, the defense minister and a member of the war cabinet, accused him of letting the nation drift into a military and civilian occupation of Gaza, which would cost Israel “blood and many victims, with no aim.” He challenged Mr. Netanyahu to rule that option out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Boucher
title: Philadelphia’s University of the Arts Announces Sudden Closing
description: The institution’s financial woes were widely known, but the announcement surprised students and faculty members.
content: The nearly 150-year-old University of the Arts in Philadelphia will close its doors June 7. Many of its 1,149 students and about 700 faculty and staff members got the news from an article in the Philadelphia Inquirer on Friday or on social media, only later getting official word from the school.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Is This Season of ‘Hacks’ Trolling Jerry Seinfeld?
description: The comedian’s philosophies about the audience and comedy are contradicted in characterizations and plot lines on the Max series.
content: So many movies and television series have shown us the misery of a stand-up comic bombing and the joy of a comedian killing. But skirting cliché, the entertaining third season of “Hacks,” which just concluded, dramatizes a more novel and pointed onstage moment: the crisis of success.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Monday Briefing: What’s Next for South Africa
description: Also, India’s elections and internet in the Amazon.
content: The African National Congress has lost its political monopoly on South Africa. Election results on Saturday showed that the party had fallen short of winning an absolute majority for the first time since the end of apartheid in 1994.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Lara Trump, R.N.C. Leader, Denounces Larry Hogan for Accepting Trump Verdict
description: Ms. Trump refused to say whether the Republicans should support Mr. Hogan, a prized recruit who gave the party a chance of picking up a Democratic Senate seat in Maryland.
content: Lara Trump, the co-chair of the Republican National Committee and former President Donald J. Trump’s daughter-in-law, on Sunday denounced Larry Hogan, the Republican Senate candidate in Maryland, for urging Americans to “respect the verdict” against Mr. Trump — criticizing a prized recruit who has given the party a chance of winning a seat that has reliably been held by Democrats.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: Grilled Soy-Basted Chicken With Spicy Cashews, a Five-Star Reader Favorite
description: “I would love to leave a review, but I’m so busy swooning and drooling, I’m not sure I can concentrate.”
content: Good morning. Julie Powell famously learned to cook by making her way through all of Julia Child’s “Mastering the Art of French Cooking,” an endeavor she chronicled in a blog that became a book and then a movie.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter S. Goodman
title: The Floating Traffic Jam That Freaked Us All Out
description: The coronavirus pandemic schooled the world in the essential role of global supply chains. Have we learned anything from it?
content: Southern California appeared to be under siege from a blockade.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Gold
title: Trump Joins TikTok, the App He Once Tried to Ban
description: The former president has recently embraced the platform as he seeks to reach younger voters.
content: Donald J. Trump has joined TikTok, the social media app that he tried to ban during his presidency but that he more recently has embraced as he and his campaign try to reach younger voters before November’s general election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: OPEC Plans a Gradual Unwinding of Production Cuts
description: The group announced after its meeting on Sunday that it would be extending production cuts into 2025 and laid out plans for phasing out voluntary cuts. Whether the strategy will work remains to be seen.
content: When officials from major oil-producing countries met on Sunday, they had a tricky task before them: To reassure shaky markets that they would continue to restrain oil supplies.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miriam Jordan
title: Faith-Based Groups That Assist Migrants Become Targets of Extremists
description: Charities that feed, clothe and shelter border crossers fear for the safety of their employees and volunteers as the election nears and the vitriol over immigration intensifies.
content: A man posing as a pest exterminator tried to gain access to a San Diego hotel that operates as a shelter for migrant families. The next day, a woman showed up claiming to be an immigrant in need of help. Workers at the shelter, run by Catholic Charities, turned away both impostors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Weisman
title: The Governor, the Wolf and the Warden: A Fresh Look at a Gianforte Hunt
description: Law enforcement officers say they were pressured to lie when Gov. Greg Gianforte of Montana killed a black wolf in 2021. He says the story is an election-year smear.
content: The game warden in Helena, Mont., received a phone call one morning in March 2021 with a request that he knew might not end well for him. His boss and friend at the Montana Fish, Wildlife and Parks Department asked him to record officially the killing of a wolf, a fairly routine request save for one detail.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Bernstein
title: After Trump’s Conviction, a National Enquirer Editor Sends His Regrets
description: For Barry Levine, a former top journalist at the supermarket tabloid, the former president’s trial was its own kind of tear-jerker.
content: Even before former President Donald J. Trump was convicted on 34 felony counts of falsifying business records to conceal a sex scandal, a verdict was being delivered on The National Enquirer.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Linda Villarosa
title: Is Nonviolent Resistance Past Its Prime?
description: In “We Refuse,” Kellie Carter Jackson explores the many forms of activism that oppressed people have resorted to and offers a more nuanced picture of their lives.
content: In his 1958 memoir “Stride Toward Freedom,” the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. laid out a series of principles — courage, friendship, spiritual transformation and so on — for combating racism and other forms of oppression. Inspired by Mahatma Gandhi and Jesus Christ, King urged that the acceptance of suffering, even violence, without retaliation put one in accord with the universe and armed just people with the power to defeat hate.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Isgur
title: Hunter Biden Should Take a Plea Deal. Quickly.
description: The case against him is strong.
content: Hunter Biden faces up to 25 years in prison if convicted on three felony gun charges in a trial that is set to begin in Wilmington, Del., on Monday. In the meantime, his father is behind in many polls, his financial benefactor is reportedly “tapped out” and his best legal arguments require gutting federal gun control laws. An embarrassing trial that he is likely to lose will only make things worse.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: As Hunter Biden’s Trial Nears, President Biden Pulls Him Close
description: President Biden has weathered years of scandals surrounding his son. But people close to both men say the president has refused to treat him as a political liability.
content: President Biden wakes up every day to a list of concerns he must address as commander in chief. He receives updates from his aides each morning on the war in Gaza and the Russian invasion of Ukraine. He calls his advisers to quiz them about the latest polls and headlines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and Damien Cave
title: In Singapore, China Warns U.S. While Zelensky Seeks Support
description: The annual Shangri-La Dialogue became a stage for competing demands on U.S. global power, including the war in Ukraine and tensions over Taiwan.
content: The competing strains on U.S. global power came into sharp focus at a security conference on Sunday, where China accused the United States of stoking tensions around Taiwan and the South China Sea, and President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine sought greater support for his embattled country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer and Danny Hakim
title: Here’s Where Trump’s Other Cases Stand
description: After being convicted in a Manhattan courtroom, the former president still faces charges in three criminal prosecutions, all of which are tangled up in procedural delays.
content: Former President Donald J. Trump’s criminal trial in Manhattan came to an end this week when a jury found him guilty of 34 counts of falsifying business records in an effort to cover up a sex scandal that threatened to upset his 2016 presidential campaign.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Yan Zhuang
title: China Lands Spacecraft on Far Side of the Moon
description: The landing brings the Chang’e-6 mission a step closer to being the first to return a sample from the part of the moon that’s never seen from Earth.
content: China successfully landed a lunar lander on the far side of the moon on Sunday morning, the country’s space agency announced, taking the mission one step closer to bringing back the first sample from the part of the moon that earthlings never see.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Terence McGinley
title: Archival Treasures ‘Hidden in Plain Sight’
description: The Times’s clippings library, with millions of pieces of reference material, can tell its own stories.
content: There are millions of newspaper articles, photographs and other archival materials in The New York Times’s clippings library, a repository known to employees as the morgue.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lynsey Chutel
title: ‘A.N.C. Has Been Humbled’: a Couple’s Vote Explains Why
description: Some South African voters welcomed the defeat of the African National Congress in last week’s elections, even as they remain wary of the country’s political future.
content: A bell tolled on TV, signaling a shift in the results tallied so far. From their home in northern Johannesburg, the Mathivha family celebrated the latest update: with the majority of votes counted, the African National Congress had earned a mere 41 percent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jessica Testa
title: The Age of Brooke Shields
description: The model and actress has three new titles: Netflix rom-com star, union boss and C.E.O. of a beauty brand aimed at women over 40.
content: Some stories are so perfect and poignant that even if we suspect they are not true, we simply do not want to know.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Choe Sang-Hun
title: Why Did North Korea Bombard the South With Trash Balloons?
description: The unusual offensive, across the world’s most heavily fortified border, is a revival of a Cold War era tactic. The South has threatened to respond by blasting K-pop.
content: North Korea launched 720 balloons across the world’s most heavily armed border overnight Saturday, hitting South Korea with their payloads: plastic bags full of cigarette butts and other trash.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas and Victor Moriyama
title: The Internet’s Final Frontier: Remote Amazon Tribes
description: Elon Musk’s Starlink has connected an isolated tribe to the outside world — and divided it from within.
content: As the speeches dragged on, eyes drifted to screens. Teenagers scrolled Instagram. One man texted his girlfriend. And men crowded around a phone streaming a soccer match while the group’s first female leader spoke.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Glenn Thrush
title: Hunter Biden to Go on Trial in Gun Case, Days After Trump Was Convicted
description: On Monday in Delaware, one of two trials will begin in which President Biden’s son will defend himself during a presidential election year.
content: Follow our live coverage of Hunter Biden’s federal gun trial.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn McCreesh
title: After Verdict, Trump Revels in Embrace of His Most Avid Base: Male Fans
description: The former president’s appearance at a U.F.C. fight in Newark on Saturday night showcased his hypermasculine appeal, and his defiance.
content: Sixteen thousand people erupted into rapture when Donald J. Trump walked into the Prudential Center in Newark at 10 p.m. Saturday to attend an Ultimate Fighting Championship match. He stayed until the grisly end, at 1:15 a.m.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas
title: After Pipes Burst in Atlanta, Many Residents Lose Water, Then Patience
description: Major main breaks resulted in closed businesses, canceled events and angry residents who were upset over a lack of updates.
content: A series of water main breaks in Atlanta caused widespread disruption on Saturday, as outages and severely reduced water pressure forced some businesses to close and infuriated residents who criticized city officials for failing to provide timely updates.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon and Lynsey Chutel
title: What’s Next for South Africa After Voters Rebuked Its Reigning Party?
description: A look at the leaders who could shape the country’s future after the African National Congress’s poor showing in elections.
content: South Africa is headed for big change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By B.D. McClay
title: Give Yourself Permission to Not Have Sex
description: Intentional periods of sexual abstinence can help us better understand the nature of our desire. If we do Dry January, why not Dry Spell July?
content: In his first letter to the Corinthians, the apostle Paul issues one of Christianity’s better-known if lesser-observed dictates: It’s best to remain unmarried, full stop. But, he continues, if people “cannot control themselves, they should marry, for it is better to marry than to burn with passion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka
title: Teacher Placed on Leave Over ‘Mock Slave Auction’ in Classroom
description: The teacher in Massachusetts, who has not been named, was placed on leave after also using a racial slur, the school superintendent said.
content: A fifth-grade teacher in Massachusetts who held a “mock slave auction” and used a racial slur in a classroom has been placed on paid administrative leave, the district superintendent said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jacob Judah
title: A Pacific Island With Ties to Taiwan Was Hacked. Was It Political?
description: Palau’s claims that China orchestrated the attack remain unproven. But it’s clear that the breach presents a danger for another ally of Palau: the United States.
content: Palau, a clump of about 350 small islands in the Pacific Ocean, has become increasingly important to the United States as China tries to build clout in the Indo-Pacific. This year, Washington finalized a long-delayed plan to give Palau hundreds of millions of dollars in aid over two decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Bright
title: Why the New Human Case of Bird Flu Is So Alarming
description: The virus is changing.
content: The third human case of H5N1, reported on Thursday in a farmworker in Michigan who was experiencing respiratory symptoms, tells us that the current bird flu situation is at a dangerous inflection point.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Glascock and Julie Bosman
title: The Ghost Trees of Chicago
description: Residents have been covering their trees in mesh to protect them from the emerging broods, and the effect is pretty eerie.
content: In May, parts of Chicago were covered for the first time in 17 years by a brood of buzzing, mating, crawling red-eyed cicadas. The city’s tiniest trees were ready.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Corbin
title: Hot Off the Presses
description: Alana Platt makes her New York Times debut.
content: Jump to: Today’s Theme | Tricky Clues
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Jacobs
title: They Revolutionized Shopping, With Tea Sandwiches on the Side
description: In “When Women Ran Fifth Avenue,” Julie Satow celebrates the savvy leaders who made Bonwit, Bendel’s and Lord & Taylor into retail meccas of their moment.
content: In 1980, Donald J. Trump made the front page of The New York Times after assaulting a pair of scantily clad women at a Fifth Avenue department store.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Opinion
title: Should Trump Be Sentenced to Prison? Two Opposing Views.
description: Two legal experts weigh in.
content: Now that Donald Trump has been convicted on 34 felony counts, his sentencing hearing looms on July 11. Below are two legal experts weighing in on the critical question of whether Mr. Trump ought to receive a prison sentence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rukmini Callimachi
title: Stuck in a Starter Home
description: Squeezed by high interest rates and record prices, homeowners are frozen in place. They can’t sell. So first-time buyers can’t buy.
content: If buying a home is an inexorable part of the American dream, so is the next step: eventually selling that home and using the equity to trade up to something bigger.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: As Challenges Pile Up, a Spate of Summitry Spotlights Western Resolve
description: Wars in Ukraine and Gaza, along with Donald J. Trump’s candidacy, are testing the Western alliance. But starting with the 80th anniversary of D-Day this week, leaders have a rare opportunity to showcase unity.
content: Western leaders are embarking on an extraordinary stretch of summitry this week, which could give them a chance to project unity to adversaries who increasingly view the West as something to be defied, disregarded or even repudiated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bernard Mokam
title: Congestion Pricing Ignites an Old Rift: Drivers vs. Transit Riders
description: As New York City prepares to roll out its tolling program on June 30, the divide between those who love their cars and those who embrace their subway lines has only grown.
content: In 2010, Filolaos Kefalas, an electrical engineer, drove a black Corvette into Manhattan for his first date with Lisa Daglian, a transit advocate. She was not impressed.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gray Beltran, Matthew Bloch, Martín González Gómez and Alex Lemonides
title: Mexico Election Results: Sheinbaum Wins
description: See results and maps for Mexico’s 2024 presidential election.
content: See results and maps for Mexico’s 2024 presidential election.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jack Nicas, Rebecca Suner and James Surdam
title: How Internet Access Is Transforming Life in This Amazon Tribe
description: Since September, the Marubo, an isolated Amazon tribe, were connected to high-speed internet through Elon Musk’s Starlink. Jack Nicas, The New York Times’s Brazil bureau chief, visited the tribe’s remote Indigenous villages to see what the internet has changed for them.
content: Since September, the Marubo, an isolated Amazon tribe, were connected to high-speed internet through Elon Musk’s Starlink. Jack Nicas, The New York Times’s Brazil bureau chief, visited the tribe’s remote Indigenous villages to see what the internet has changed for them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nikolay Nikolov, Yousur Al-Hlou, Masha Froliak and Natalie Reneau
title: How We Found 46 Ukrainian Children Taken by Russian Officials
description: The New York Times traced how a web of politicians aligned with President Vladimir Putin’s party carried out a campaign to permanently transfer Ukrainian children from Kherson.
content: The New York Times traced how a web of politicians aligned with President Vladimir Putin’s party carried out a campaign to permanently transfer Ukrainian children from Kherson.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Storyful
title: Wildfire Near San Francisco Grows to Several Thousand Acres
description: The blaze, the fast-spreading Corral Fire, is California’s largest so far this wildfire season and has shut down major highways and prompted residents to flee their homes.
content: The blaze, the fast-spreading Corral Fire, is California’s largest so far this wildfire season and has shut down major highways and prompted residents to flee their homes.
source.name: The New York Times
